bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, July 7, 1952

div1.p: Hench discusses the rediscovery of Camp Lazear and his desire to erect a Cuban-American Memorial in honor of both Finlay and Reed on the site. He requests permission to personally pay for the construction of a suitable cover to protect Building No. 1.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, July 7, 1952
div1.p:
duplicate
pg. 1
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
July 7, 1952 Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:

As you know, I have been interested greatly in the dramatic story of the con-
quest of yellow fever and have been visiting Havana since about 1939, collecting
data concerning the work of Dr. Carlos Finlay and his assistant, Dr. Delgado
which was begun in 1881, and that of Major Walter Reed and his associates done
between 1900 and 1902.

During my several delightful visits to Havana in connection with my study, I
have seen many Cuban physicians, government personalities and other Cubans and
feel that I have many wonderful friends in Cuba.

During all these years it has been my firm hope and belief that certain unfortunate
and undignified controversies (which have taken place in our respective countries,
and which have concerned “who did this and who did that,” and how much credit
should be given to each person) could be brought amicably to an end at long
last. So very great were the services rendered to the whole world by the men
who conquered yellow fever that there is more than glory enough for each!

In 1940 I was able, with the help of Mr. John Moran and Mr. Luis Pogolotti of
Havana, to rediscover the site of Camp Lazear where Major Walter Reed and his
associates did their work. To my delight I found that Camp Lazear had been part
of the old Finca San Jose and that Dr. Finlay had carried out one or two of his
very earliest experiments (concerning the mosquito and yellow fever) in the
permanent house, or quinta, of this very same Finca San Jose. (On one of my
visits to Havana I visited Dr. Carlos Finlay's son, Dr. Charles Finlay and
confirmed this fact. I have notes to that effect written by Dr. Charles Fin-
lay in his own handwriting on certain pages of the book he gave me, his own
book about his father.).

In summary: in the main house (quinta) of the Finca San Jose were carried
out one or two of the earliest experiments by Dr. Carlos Finlay in 1883, and
in certain little wooden buildings (“Buildings Number One and Two”) erected
at the rear of this same Finca San Jose (on a part of it used temporarily and
named “Camp Lazear”) were carried out the concluding experiments of Major
Reed and his associates in the fall of 1900 and early spring of 1901.

This coincidence seemed to me most fortuitous, a very happy one. Finding the
remains of Major Reed's little Building Number One still standing, I thought
these remains afforded a unique opportunity for interested persons to unite
their efforts to the end that the little caseta and a small portion of the
adjacent land (where Camp Lazear was) might be preserved and that on this
spot would be erected a “Cuban-American Memorial” in honor of both Dr. Finlay
and Dr. Reed and their various associates and volunteers (such as Dr. Delgado,
also Padre Urra and other volunteers of Finlay; Drs. Carroll, Agramonte and
Lazear, also Messrs. Moran, Kissinger and other volunteers of Reed et al).
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
July 7, 1952

It has been my belief that Cuban and American Medical, Governmental and other
personages could unite wholeheartedly to honor jointly the memories and deeds
of these great humanitarians, benefactors and “citizens” of the whole world.

In connection with this idea I have visited on my several trips to Havana many
distinguished Cubans in medical and governmental circles who seemed to be not
only pleased but enthusiastic about the project. They have helped in many
ways. I have also told many of my own countrymen of this proposed venture and
found them equally interested and desirous of being helpful.

Certain legal and practical difficulties (related to ownership of the little
portion of land where Camp Lazear was and where the caseta still is, also
related to the type of memorial best suited for the location and for the
purposes of the Havana and Marianao health departments, etc.) and also my
four years of duty in our Army Medical Corps prevented me and my Cuban friends
from crystallizing a definite plan or starting a definite campaign to raise
money in my country and in yours. But preliminary drawings and ideas were
presented to several of your distinguished countrymen and these plans re-
ceived their general approval.

The little caseta was “declared” a national monument by the Council of Ministers
(Consejo de Ministros) in the spring of 1947 (I believe that was the time).
But the approval of the Council (aprobo el Consejo) was not announced until
November 1947 (e.g. El Pais, pages 1 and 3, November 13, 1947). Despite this
declaration and approval in 1947, no effort was made to protect the caseta
from the ravages of time or from the recurring hurricanes, nor was any money
set aside even for the temporary protection of the caseta.

During the visit to Habana that Mrs. Hench and I made in March 1948 I re-
quested permission from several Cuban personages to be allowed to donate
$1,000.00 of my own money so that a protective galvanized iron or other
suitable cover could be erected at once to enclose the caseta and protect
it thus temporarily until appropriate plans and monies could be developed
at leisure. But because the caseta had been named a “national monument”
Senor Adrian Macia, the owner of the adjacent land, had no authority to let
me do anything to the caseta. Then I was granted a cordial interview with
your Vice-President Cardenas. He was gracious and interested in our plan,
but said that it would not be appropriate for Cuba to permit me, a private
citizen, to spend my own money on such temporary expenses; he said that he
would try to obtain the necessary funds from the Cuban Government in an ap-
priate manner.

Meanwhile the ravages of time would, presumably, continue to affect the
caseta, a “national monument” in name only. Stymied in this manner, I did
not know how I could make any proposition to my own countrymen in the
government or of the American Medical Association. But I was greatly en-
couraged when a Cuban friend sent me a copy of El Mundo, March 25, 1948, in
which it was announced that $50,000 was designated by “El Consejo de Ministros”
as a preliminary sum to be expended for the preservation of the caseta. I
believe that Dr. Andreu was the chief sponsor, probably with Vice-President
Cardenas, Dr. Presno and your good self as additional friends of this movement.
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
July 7, 1952

In April 1948, I was informed that, although the Cuban Minister of Finance
had signed the decree allotting the $50,000, the decree had not yet been pub-
lished in the Official Gazette. Shortly thereafter there was a change in the
administration; and I was greatly disappointed to learn that the plan had
fallen through, and the money was never made available.

But in 1951 I was informed that, through the continuing interest and sponsor-
ship of Dr. Andreu and others, plans for the preservation of Camp Lazear and
the caseta had been revived and that $25,000 had been set aside for its preserva-
tion. Various Cuban friends sent me several Habana newspaper clippings about
this: for example, clippings from El Pais, April 25, 1951 and November 16,
1951 and from Excelsior, December 10, 1951.

Many Americans were delighted to hear of these revived plans which I men-
tioned to the Surgeon General of the United States Army and others.

On our recent (January 1952) visit to Habana, Mrs. Hench and I were delighted
indeed to hear of the progression of these plans from Dr. Andreu, yourself
and others. I was happy to express publicly my great delight and approval,
and to offer my continuing help (if my help could be useful), during the little
talk I gave at a Rotary Club luncheon in Marianao, also during the little
speech I made when Dr. Andreu and others honored me greatly on the occasion
of the Condecoration of the Finlay Medal. I also was delighted to discuss
the preservation of Camp Lazear and the caseta, when I was interviewed by a
certain newspaper reporter (Avance, January 25, 1952).

Let me assure you that my enthusiasm for a “Cuban-American memorial” is
still as strong as ever. I realize that with the relatively small amount
of money allotted ($25,000) your Ministry of Public Health and your Depart-
ment of Public Works can only do so much at this time. I am hopeful that
my own countrymen can join with yours so that, once the grounds around the
caseta have been properly developed into a park, a permanent and suitable
protection for the caseta can be erected, perhaps in connection either with
a small “Cuban-American Medical Museum” or, better yet, in connection with
an even more suitable affair; a useful, “living memorial” in the form of a
small public health project or unit. As long as the historic caseta remains
uncovered, exposed continuously to the elements, the historically minded
people will be unhappy about the dangerous impermanency of this memorial
which could be used so felicitously to strengthen greatly the bonds of
friendship and understanding between our two governments and between the
medical professions of our two countries.

Permit me to ask you to express to Dr. Andreu and to others who may be con-
cerned my own personal gratitude for the very real progress that has been
made. When the little park is dedicated I hope indeed that American news
services will be advised because the ceremonies will interest and please
a great many in this country.

Permit me to offer to Dr. Andreu, to yourself and others my services in
developing further plans for financial and other cooperation.

Always sincerely yours,
P. S. Hench, M.D.

Addendum to letter of July 7, 1952

Pedro, will you now let me discuss with you, as one good friend to another,
a more delicate matter that has given me and others some concern, a growing
concern, I might add.

You will recall with what pleasure I discussed briefly with Doctor Andreu
last January his plans for the preservation of the caseta at Camp Lazear.
I have been well aware of your own important and continuing influence in
these developments. You will recall how happy I was to go with you to the
Ministry of Public Works to see the preliminary blue-prints for the park. I
am sure you will remember that after expressing my general approval and
pleasure, I hesitated a moment and then called your attention to two places
on the blue-print: (1) the title or heading on the original blue print
read (as I recall it) “Anteproyecto de Parque Finlay”; (2) the little caseta
(Reed's “Building Number One”), was erroneously designated “caseta de Finlay.”

I was about to leave Habana and certainly did not want to become involved in
the old unhappy controversy with you and other wonderful Cuban friends of
mine. But I felt that in fairness to all concerned I had to discuss this
quietly with you. When I called these to your attention you may recall I
said that I and others in your country as well as mine had hoped that the
memorial might be called “The Cuban-American Memorial” or “The Cuban-
American Medical Memorial.” Perhaps even more specifically the land might be
called “Parque Lazear” or “Campamento Lazear,” continuing its actual historical
name, whereas the future memorial building could be called “The Cuban-American
Medical Memorial” which will house, among other things and souvenirs,
“Building Number One.”

However I also said that if your government saw fit to discard these or
similar suggestions and to name the site of Camp Lazear “Parque Finlay” it
would be less appropriate but perhaps “acceptable” to Cuba's American friends
provided “Reed's Building Number One” was properly identified.

I was relieved when you smiled at my remarks. After talking volubly in
Spanish with the architects you reassured me that the title of the project
was tentative and that the “caseta de Finlay” was a frank mistake. Your
explanation was quite simple and valid; as I recall it you said, “Phil,
that's just a mistake which must be and will be corrected. After all,
these draftsmen in the Department of Public Works aren't medical historians.
They know nothing about yellow fever, Camp Lazear, Walter Reed or ‘Building
Number One’. We'll fix that up alright.”

Thus reassured that the work was to be a joint memorial in honor of Finlay
and the American investigators, I asked if I might have two blue-prints as
I wanted later to make copies and send them to interested Americans including
our State Department in Washington and the Surgeon General of the Army, so
that their sympathetic interest and appreciation of what your Government was
doing could be expressed. When you translated my request to the architect
he promised to make available to me “corrected copies.”

In due time I received two corrected blue-prints now entitled “Anteproyecto
de Parque en el Antiguo ‘Campamento Lazear’.” I had copies made here and was
about to send them out when I noticed that the caseta of Reed was still labelled
“caseta de Finlay.” I concluded that this was a simple error still uncorrected,
and meant to write you about it so that I could get a true, corrected copy to
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
July 7, 1952
send to Washington and elsewhere with my personal account of what Cuba was
planning to do. But my letter to you about this was delayed because of the
press of medical work, attendance at medical meetings, etc.

Meanwhile I have received (quite unsolicited by me) from various friends
and acquaintances in Cuba a number of newspaper clippings that first disturbed
them and have since disturbed me somewhat also. There are in Cuba, many people
(mostly Cubans, but also many Americans resident in Cuba, besides those in the
American embassy) who now know something about the historical significance of
“Camp Lazear” and “Building Number One”. During the past ten to twelve years
several newspaper articles in Cuban newspapers have discussed the “rediscovery”
of Camp Lazear. The matter was discussed also on the radio once or twice. These
people have interested themselves sufficiently to know the relationship between
the work of Finlay and that of the Americans, to know something about Finlay's
early experiments and the later ones of the Americans and their associates at
Camp Columbia and later at “Camp Lazear”.

Being thus informed they have been concerned by the continuation of the
newspaper errors. As a reader one can readily ignore or explain away or condone
one or two erroneous newspaper accounts. But when such continues to be pub-
lished one is inclined to wonder whether the newspapers really do wish to get
matters straight.

Because I have recently received two or three new clippings which continue
the errors I have decided I had better call them to your attention and ask you
for advice as to what should be done.

The time is approaching when “Camp Lazear” (regardless of whether or not it
is called that) is to be dedicated. As I understand it the dedication will be
during an international congress. Presumably American physicians, perhaps
American medical officers and other personnel will be there. It would be quite
embarassing and unfortunate if the affair were the subject of misunderstanding
and regret.

It is quite possible that the concern of my correspondents in Cuba (and of
myself) is entirely unnecessary. It is also possible that these clippings have
not been brought to your attention, or that, reading each one at widely spaced
intervals you did not appreciate the unfavorable reaction that they are develop-
ing in certain quarters. Like me, you probably ignored the early ones. But
although I did not worry about them I did keep them all in my files and perhaps
you will best understand the situation if I transcribe excerpts from several
representative ones in consecutive order.

Do you not agree with me that someone in authority should very soon explain
the situation more clearly and accurately to the Habana newspapers? If this is
not done soon, the papers will either not get the story right at the time of the
dedication or they will then receive such a “different story” that they will
wonder why they were not completely informed earlier.

If at the time of the dedication the papers should continue the errors and
perpetuate the misunderstanding, would it not tend to undo what Dr. Andreu, Dr.
Ramos (who once wrote a paper about Camp Lazear and recommended the erection of
a joint memorial), you and I and many others have been trying to do.

Here is a grand opportunity for a joint memorial project. I personally
always speak and write about the amazing work of Finlay in connection with my
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
July 7, 1952
papers and talks on this subject. Having heard my illustrated talk in Washing-
ton a few years ago you can vouch for that. I agree heartily that my country-
men do not know nearly as much as they should about Finlay. I am seeing to it
that they will know and, as you know, I have spent much time trying to learn
the details of his life and work. When my book appears I feel sure that justice
will be done to Finlay as well as to my countrymen and in the very nature of
things several chapters will have to be all about Finlay.

But certainly Reed, Agramonte, Carroll and Lazear and their associates did
a great service to Cuba as well as to the world. If the newspapers are permitted
to continue to speak of “Building Number One” as the “caseta de Finlay” you and I
and the many broad minded physicians and governmental personages who want so very
much to do honor to all concerned will have reason for regrets and will feel that
our efforts to develop mutual admiration and esteem have been unsuccessful. We
want no partisanship in this fine venture and we must not let this venture be
spoiled by repertorial ignorance or misunderstanding!

Pedro, will you please read over the appended quotations from selected clip-
pings and give me your reaction. I do hope you can reassure me that the careless
or uninformed reporters do not have any official approval. What should be done?
What can I do? Do you think I should write Dr. Andreu or Dr. Ramos or Dr. Presno
or the mayor of Marianao? Should I write to Mrs. Smith, President of F.I.M.?
You might be able to discuss the matter briefly and quietly with Dr. Andreu, and
he could “brief” the reporters accurately at the proper time. But the repertorial
build-up for the dedication of the little park cannot be far off. So it seems
that the papers should soon be told what is the happy truth, namely that the
dedication of a memorial on the Finca San Jose is so wonderfully appropriate
because this place unites, as no other place in the world can do, the humanitarian
works and beneficient spirits of all the medical heroes concerned!

Always your friend,
P. S. Hench, M.D.
